document.docAuthor: Siewert, Ricardo Russo, Zacca, Thamara, Mielke, Olaf Hermann Hendrik & Casagrande, Mirna Martins
document.docOrigin: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society 177 (3)
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic revision and cladistic analysis of the genus Sophista Plotz, 1879 (Lepidoptera: Hesperiidae) with description of a new species from north-east Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic revision and cladistic analysis of the genus Sophista Plotz, 1879 (Lepidoptera: Hesperiidae) with description of a new species from north-east Brazil
Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society

subSubSection.paragraph:
Sophista aristoteles plinius
; Evans, 1953 ; Cat. Amer. Hesp. 3: 42, pl. 29 (male gen.). Ebert, 1969 ;. Jour. Lep. Soc. 23: Suppl. 3: 39. Bridges, 1988b ; Cat. Hesp. 1: 150; 2: 55. K. Brown, 1992 ; in Morellato. Hist. Nat. Japi , p. 176, fig. 16(d). K. Brown & Freitas, 2000 ; Bol. Mus. Biol. Mello Leit ao~ , n.s., Sta. Teresa, 11/12: 111. Mielke, 2004 ;. Hesperioidea, p. 55, in Lamas (ed.). Checklist: Part 4A, Hesperioidea- Papilionoidea, in Heppner (ed.).
Atlas Neotrop. Lep. 5A.
Mielke, 2005 . Cat. Amer. Hesperioidea 3: 711.

(no genus)
plinius
; Beattie, 1976 . Rhop. Direct. , p. 235.

Sophista plinius
resembles
S. aristoteles
, but can be distinguished by the narrow white band on DW. Left valva with harpe approximately seven times longer than wide; ampulla with well-developed spine and harpe with another spine in its internal dorsal region. Right valva with harpe approximately ten times longer than wide; ampulla with two welldeveloped spines, one dorsally and other spine close to inner margin; harpe with median – dorsal projection with spines, curved inwards. Distal portion of aedeagus lanceolate. Left projection of sterigma covered with spines that are less developed than in
S. aristoteles
; ventrally with sclerotized and developed projection in right basal third; right lobe present.

Sophista plinius Plotz, 1882
was described based on one male specimen from South America. Evans (1953) considered
S. plinius
as a subspecies of
S. aristoteles
, and this allocation has been followed until the present study. Despite their superficial resemblance,
S. plinius
and
S. aristoteles
have very distinctive male and female genitalia.

The holotype male is deposited in the ZMHU , with the following labels (separated by slashes): / Typus / 4954 / Brasil Virm /
plinius Pl.
type 5954
/.

Sophista plinius
is distributed in central – eastern and southern Brazil , especially in localities at higher altitudes in the Atlantic Forest ( Mielke, 2005 ) ( Fig. 76 ).
